title: Housebound woman unable to speak told she is fit to work by DWP
text:
Debra Barrass suffers from advanced emphysema and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) (Picture: NCJ Media)

A woman who is so sick she is unable to speak has been left feeling suicidal after the Department for Work and Pensions stopped her benefits.

Debra Barrass, 47, was deemed fit to work despite suffering from advanced emphysema and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

The condition leaves sufferers with shortness of breath and has progressed so much that Ms Barrass can barely talk and struggles to perform even the most minor tasks.

Since her diagnosis in 2010, she had been receiving Employment Support Allowance (ESA) and Personal Independent Payment (PIP).

But despite the debilitating condition, Ms Barrass was forced to attend a mandatory work capability assessment, where she was deemed fit to work.

She said: ‘I struggle from day-to-day, doing absolutely anything. They have said I am fit for work.

My COPD is in the advanced stage and the tests they give you – I am not hitting the targets. I’m absolutely exhausted. I struggle to get up the stairs.

‘I struggle to get out of the house often because I struggle so much. I’m really housebound.’

She was told she was fit to work after a DWP assessment (Picture: NCJ Media)

Ms Barrass, from Wallsend near Newcastle, said she had been receiving £220 every fortnight as part of her ESA and another £300 a month from PIP.

This week the DWP asked Ms Barrass to attend a reassessment and her £300 a month has been restored until a hearing takes place.

However this slight respite has done little to help, as the situation has taken its toll on her mental health and has left her suffering from anxiety and depression.

She said: ‘When they stopped all my money I didn’t have a thing. I just want to kill myself. I’m really, really struggling.’

A DWP spokesperson said: ‘We’re committed to ensuring that disabled people and those with health conditions get the support they’re entitled to.

‘Decisions about entitlement to ESA are made based on all the information provided, including from a GP or medical specialist.

‘Following a request from Ms Barrass we are reviewing our decision to find her fit for work. She continues to receive support through Personal Independence Payment.’
